title: red star stung late in exciting league match
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwards.RJD-sponsored Red Star welcomed Baljaffray to the Joint Campus G pitch last Saturday where the sides played out a thrilling three-all draw in a match which swung in either direction in horrendous conditions.The sides exchanged goals in the first half, with Stuart MacLean reacting quickest in the box after the Baljaffray keeper couldn’t hold a Fraser Talbot shot and the striker scored to net his eleventh goal in eight games.Baljaffray forced a succession of corners near the end of the half and were on level terms when Red Star were only able to partially clear a corner which fell to the away side’s full back and his shot via the aid of a deflection went past young Leon Murphy in the Star goal. -Into the second half and Star could have retaken the lead when Aaron Moore latched onto a drilled cross from strike partner Stuart MacLean, however, his effort was blocked by an excellent save from the Baljaffray number one.The visitors took the lead after  minutes when a cross caused confusion in the Star defence and the Baljaffray forward had the simple task of finishing into an empty net from close range.Star huffed and puffed for an equaliser, however, they were frustrated by excellent goalkeeping until the goal came in fortuitous circumstances after a long ball was nodded past his own keeper by the Baljaffray centre back meaning the sides were level with  minutes to go.Star took the lead with five minutes remaining when Aaron Moore was able to burst clear of the Baljaffray backline and finish well into the far corner to make it -.This should have been enough to see Star over the line but Baljaffray scrambled a late equaliser when Star again failed to clear a free kick and the ball was bundled over the line to see the match end -.Lochgilphead Red Star are on their travels on Saturday November  when they face their toughest test of the season so far as they take on league leaders and title favourites Arthurlie.

title: argyllshire advertiser leader column november 19 2021
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwards.Maybe it is a sign that the young folk causing damage at Blarbuie Woodland are maturing, but it was good to hear that some, at least, had gone back to help clean up their mess.Whatever their motivation, good on them.The night-time antics there over quite a period have been pointless, infantile and regularly dangerous. And do these kids# families not know where they are in the evenings The carrot of working with ACT, the police and wider community to create something positive is on offer for young people.But so too is the stick, eventhis is something that most would rather avoid using.Let#s hope they continue to grow out of getting kicks from damaging things which folk have put their heart and souls into creating for others.Last year#s Remembrance was strange in the pandemic.Maybe we felt the need this year to reconnect with tradition, or perhaps the past  months has offered a little insight into the infinitely more arduous trials faced by those we remembered last Sunday.The fact that so many people came out on a cold day was heart-warming.

title: red star face busby in league
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwards.Subscribe NowAfter last weekend#s SAFL Division One tie away to Claremont was postponed, Lochgilphead Red Star this weekend face Busby at the Ropework park.Star currently sit in the top half of the table, having played one or two games fewer than their rivals above them in what is shaping up to be a competitive league.The match on Saturday December  starts at pm, and a good home support at the Ropework would be welcome.A win for the Mid Argyll outfit would see them move up to third in the table.

title: scotland-women-head-dubai-february-cup-qualifiers
story: THE WOMENS edition of the Rugby World Cup  Final Qualication Tournament will take place on  and  February  at The Sevens Stadium in Dubai.Scotland will compete alongside Samoa, Colombia and the winner of the Hong Kong v Kazakhstan playoff for the last remaining place at Rugby World Cup  in New Zealand, now due to take place between  Octoberndash November, .The Final Qualication Tournament will operate in a semi-final, final format over two match days.This is the first time the womenrsquos edition of Rugby World Cup has featured a Final Qualication Tournament offering teams a second pathway to qualy for RWC  with the winner booking their place in Pool A alongside hosts New Zealand, Australia and Wales next year.Eleven teams have already booked their place at Rugby World Cup , including New Zealand, England, France, Canada, USA, Australia and Wales, who qualied through their final ranking at Ireland , and South Africa, Fiji, Italy and Japan who qualied through their regions.Rugby World Cup  Tournament Director, Alison Hughes, said: ldquoWe are pleased to be able to share the details of the Rugby World Cup  Final Qualication Tournament. A first for a womenrsquos edition of a Rugby World Cup the tournament offers teams a second opportunity to qualy for the pinnacle event and we anticipate a thrilling contest between competing teams in Dubai in February.Tom Burwell, The Sevens Stadium General Manager, said, ldquoWe are hugely excited to host world-class womenrsquos XVs rugby at The Sevens Stadium. It will be the first time such a competition has taken place in the UAE. With the Emirates Dubai s ing over the next two weekends, itrsquos an exciting time for rugby in the region. We are honoured to be working with World Rugby once more in delivering international rugby. With the winner going onto New Zealand and RWC , we are excited to be part of a nationrsquos journey to the very top of the womenrsquos game..removeThe RWC  Final Qualication Tournament will be live streamed across World Rugby and RWC  digital and social s.Rugby World Cup  will be the showpiece event in womenrsquos rugby union s, with the first tickets for Rugby World Cup  selling out in minutes. Tournament organisers are calling on fans to secure their tickets early to avoid disappointment.

title: work-start-soon-gala-fairydean-rovers-stand
story: GALA Fairydean Rovers hope to reopen their iconic Netherdale Stand for the start of next season.The Peter Womersley designed building has been closed since winter  due to public health and safety concerns associated with spalling concrete.A structural assessment was initially conducted in  highlighting the required repairs needed to the stand.Concrete Repairs Limitedhas been appointed to carry out a range of improvements to the category A listed building. The work includes concrete repairs to the stand and turnstiles, drainage improvements and aesthetic enhancements around the stand to restore some of its original features.The work will be funded by Scottish Borders Council within this yearrsquos capital budget along with a contribution from the Gala Fairydean Rovers Football Community Trust.Councillor Gordon Edgar, executive member for roads and infrastructure, said: ldquoAnyone who is familiar with the town of Galashiels will recognise the iconic architecture of the Netherdale Stand and its importance to the town.ldquoIrsquom extremely excited to see work on repairing the building to its former glory progress with the appointment of an experienced contractor.ldquoEnsuring its long-term future by carrying out these necessary refurbishments will allow future generations to benefit from it andthe stand to its former glory.Murray Souter, regional director for Scotland at Concrete Repairs Limited, said: ldquoConcrete Repairs Limited are delighted to be entrusted with the refurbishment of this iconic structure and our team are looking forward to spending the spring and summer months of  in Galashiels working.ldquoTogether with Scottish Borders Council and their design team, we willthe stand to its original glory, looking great, structurally sound, and ready to cope with a full complement of excited Gala Fairydean Rovers fans.The news was also welcomed by Ross Buchan, chairman of Gala Fairydean Rovers Community Trust..removeHe said: ldquoThe stand repair project has been a long journey which began for us in October . The stand is part of our architectural and historic heritage and itrsquos listing places a duty on us, the community, to preserve the structure for future generations.ldquoWe have now reached a signicant stage on this journey, where, Scottish Borders Council have appointed of the principal contractor to carry out the works. We welcome Concrete Repairs Limitedonto the project and look forward to working in cooperation and partnership with them also.ldquoIt will be a day to celebrate when the stand is opened to the public, club and community where we can once again make full use of this very important facility.ldquoThe project has benefitted from working in cooperation and partnership with Scottish Borders Council, Historic Environment Scotland, Fallago Environmental Fund, Live Borders, Gala Fairydean Rovers Football Club, Gala Fairydean Rovers Football Club Community Trust and our very experienced design team.

title: rugby-fans-treat-weekend
story: A feast of live rugby is taking place in the Borders this weekend.There will be a huge Borders derby on Saturday when Hawick make the short trip up the A to Philiphaugh where they will face Selkirk in the Premiership. Elsewhere Jed-Forest head west to meet Glasgow Hawks.In the National League Division One Biggar host Stirling Wolves, Gala face Ayr at Netherdale, Kelso make the long trip to Inverness to face Highland and Melrose host Boroughmuir at the Greenyards.In the National League Division Two Peebles host Kirkcaldy at the Gytes.In the National League Division Three Berwick are at home to Murrayfield Wanderers.In the National East League One Duns are in the capital to face Broughton.In the National East League Two Hawick Linden are away to Leith.In the National East League Three Earlston host Edinburgh Northern.In the Reserve East League One Selkirk A face Hawick Force and Jed-Forest A face Stewartrsquos Melville in Edinburgh.In the Reserve East League Two Peebles Reds are away to Edinburgh Accies, Kelso Sharks host Gala A in a Borders derby and Melrose Storm are in East Lothian to face Preston Lodge A.On Sunday Kelso Ladies are away to Annan Ladies.Elsewhere Hawickrsquos Lisa Thomson and former Melrose player Ross McCann will feature for Team GB Womenrsquos and Menrsquos s teams in the Dubai Sevens. The group stages will be held on Saturday with the latter stages and finals on Sunday.As always check before you travel to make sure that the game is on.A round up of the results will be available on the Borderand Peeblesshire News at noon on Sunday.

title: 900-keep-safe-places-available-scotland
story: TODAYis International Day of Persons with Disabilities and Police Scotland say that they aim to ensure that people with disabilities or long-term conditions, both visible and hidden, are able to access their police service when they need it.Previously people with disabilities have told officers that they sometimes feel less safe where they live.In response Police Scotland say that they are working with local communities to create Keep Safe places for anyone feeling vulnerable when out in the community. There are currently over  across Scotland and the network continues to grow.Officers also say that taking part in the lsquoYour Police Surveyrsquo is one way for people to express their views and needs.Responses to Your Police Survey helps officers identy and eliminate obstacles and barriers for anyone who needs them and they would encourage everyone to take part to influence policing in their area.Your Police Survey is available in easy read and British Sign Language formats.Take part here http:ow.ly BXwHPh

title: massive-game-ahead-vale-leithen
story: VALE of Leithento Lowland League action on Saturday with a trip to face in-form Stirling University.And manager Grant Sandison believes thathis players continue with the same form that they displayed in their last two league games then they are more than capable of causing problems for the students.Vale have not played a competitive game since November  due to having been eliminated in the early stages of the South Challenge Cup and the Scottish Cup.During that break Sandison has been completing his UEFA B Licence Course at the Oriam in Edinburgh and he managed to arrange a couple of friendlies to keep the squad ticking over.Last week Vale lost - to Peebles Rovers and on Tuesday a match against Preston Athletic was abandoned due to adverse weather.Stirling have been in a good run of form recently beating Gala Fairydean Rovers - at Netherdale in the South Challenge Cup."When I first took over, they were down the bottom of the table along with Gretna and Edinburgh University," Sandison said. ldquoBut they have picked up lately and are showing consistency. They are in a good run of form and have done well, taking eight points from their last four games and are in a  position in the table.ldquoI watched them against East Stirling and had them watched against Gala so we are well briefed and I know they have some good young players but I believe thatwe can take the level of performance we showed against Bonnyrigg and Spartans then we can cause them problems.ldquoWe have a couple of things in the pipeline including a possible loan signing and hopefully it will happen before Saturday.

title: galashiels-great-tapestry-ticket-sale-figures-really-good
story: FIGURES around the number of tickets sold for the Great Tapestry centre have been described as ldquoreally good.The visitor attraction, which opened in Galashiels in August, was discussed at a full council meeting on Thursday, November .During the open questions section of the virtual gathering, Galashiels councillor Harry Scott asked how many paying customers have visited and how much revenue had been made.Responding, fellow Galashiels councillor Euan Jardine, of the Conservatives, said that , tickets have been bought, with pound, generated since its opening to the public.According to Mr Jardine, those numbers are ldquoin line with the revised business case projections made in February which included coronavirus implications on visitor numbers.Mr Scott, an independent representative, said: ldquoThatrsquos quite gratying. In these dficult times those figures are very good.ldquoI look forward to the facility enjoying better times ahead.Ahead of the centre opening, the council said it would ldquoattract over , visitors to Galashiels each year ndash creating  jobs and almost pound, of extra spending per annum.

title: electric-vehicle-charging-points-borders-report-recommend-fee
story: OWNERS of electric vehicles in the Borders could soon have to pay to charge their vehicle, it has been revealed.Selkirkshire councillor Gordon Edgar, the councilrsquos executive member for infrastructure, travel and transport, told a meeting last week that an upcoming report will recommend the local authority charges for the service.The plans could be put to elected officials as early as January, according to Mr Edgar.Responding to an open question from Hawick representative Davie Paterson on the issue, the independent councillor said: ldquoA condition of earlier Transport Scotland grant funding for electric vehicle charging points was that they were free at the point to encourage the uptake of electric vehicles.ldquoThis condition has now been removed and Scottish Borders Council, like other local authorities, should be considering introducing a charging regime.He added: ldquoA report on the issue is currently being prepared and will recommend that the council introduces a charging regime going forward.Mr Edgar told the meeting that the total cost to the council for the charging points last year was pound,.Meanwhile, Borders MP John Lamont says that an out of order charging point at Tweedbank Railway Station is ldquonot helping people in the Borders use electric vehicles.Figures from the Department for Transport show that there are a total of  electric vehicle charging devices available for public use in the region.But Mr Lamont, Conservative MP for Berwickshire, Roxburgh and Selkirk, says the station charger has been out of action for two months.ldquoI am keen to see electric vehicle use become more practical for people in the Scottish Borders, he said. ldquoHowever, cases like the broken charging point at Tweedbank Station are not helping.ldquoWe need to make sure we have a fully-ing electric vehicle charging network. That is why I have written to Scottish Borders Council to try and get the charging point fixed as quickly as possible..removeldquoAs we continue to increase the number of EV charging points here in the Borders, we must ensure that they are well maintained.The Borders is set to benefit from pound, of UK Government funding to support the development of electric vehicle charging points, according to Mr Lamont.On the funding, he said: ldquoI am very pleased that almost pound, of funding will go towards the expansion of our EV charging point network as part of the UKrsquos community renewal fund.ldquoI also appreciate that Scottish Borders Council will be taking on the responsibility of looking after them.

title: peebles-high-quality-path-network-plans-lodged-council
story: PEEBLES could be set for a number of ldquohigh quality walking trails after plans were filed with the council.Proposals to improve the current network while also creating new paths are outlined in an application prepared by Laurence Gould Partnership Ltd at the request of Benson Wemyss Farms.The current situation in the area to the west of the town is ldquonot ideal, providing an opportunity to link to other routes and improve ldquothe overall quality of the local path network.ldquoThe farm is a strong supporter of hillwalking and public access, having set up the highly successful Tweed Walk in partnership with Border Council [Scottish Borders Council], and has applied to the Agri-Environment  Climate Scheme for grant aid in order to improve public access across the farm, providing improved links and connectivity, improved path conditions and accessible paths for all, a report submitted as part of the application reads.ldquoThe farm has a number of existing footpaths that will be improved via the scheme, but the scheme will also create a number of new footpaths for users to enjoy.ldquoPeebles is rapidly becoming a destination for enjoying the outdoors and the woods around Neidpath are increasingly used as an important asset by the community.The business is proposing to ldquoincrease the value of the path network to the local community.According to the report, the new routes proposed include linking two core paths through the Jedderfield Plantation.On that plan, the papers state: ldquoThere are a vast range of heavily used paths through these woodlands that turn to mush during the winter. This project aims to make them accessible for more people throughout the year.A new path from the southwest section of South Park Wood along the edge of the River Tweed to the Old Manor Bridge is also outlined.Existing pathways to be upgraded are located throughout South Park Wood and alongside the River Tweed, along the old Symington, Biggar, and Broughton Railway line, according to the report..removeThe business farms at Edston Farm, located immediately to the west of Peebles.Holiday lets, a horse livery and a wedding venue are currently operated by the business, the papers state.

title: borders-gift-card-proposed-help-boost-high-streets
story: PLANS for a gt card that allows you to spend money at local businesses will be discussed by senior councillors on Tuesday .The national initiative is designed to help local retailers and high streets, according to papers put to the executive committee before next weekrsquos meeting.People can choose the amount of money to load onto the gt card and spend it within businesses that have signed up to the scheme, according to Scottish Borders Council .The view from the council is that the Scotland Loves Local Gt Card initiative would be ldquoworth trying considering the dficulties businesses have experienced during the COVID- pandemic.ldquoThe idea behind the gt card is to try and encourage people to spend money in the local community, thereby helping to support local businesses and the local supply chain, the report states. ldquoLike any other gt card, you can choose the amount of money to load onto the card.ldquoHowever, the key dference in this case is that the money can only be spent within the boundaries of the Scottish Borders and with businesses that have signed up to the scheme.ldquoThe gt cards will feature a -digit MasterCard number, CVV and expiry date allowing them to be used online at independent and national retailers alike, as long as the retailer has a physical presence in the local authority area and is making a contribution to the local economy.It adds: ldquoOur understanding is that neighbouring local authorities such as Dumfries and Galloway and Midlothian councils have already signed up to the scheme and East Lothian Council already had a gt card scheme in place which they believe to be worthwhile.If approved, it will cost the council around pound, annually to market and promote the scheme, according to the papers.It is proposed that SBC trials the scheme ldquoover the short to medium term.A review of the scheme will be undertaken after a full year of operation to help gauge the success of the project, with the results then presented to elected members. The gt card project was launched in July by Scotlandrsquos Towns Partnership.

title: west-linton-host-first-live-coffee-concert
story: A BORDERS village is set to host its first live coffee concert.During the coronavirus pandemic the West Linton Village Centre hosted a number of virtual music events, however, the centre will now welcome a live audience for Twogether Duo.Twogether Duo, formed of Alena Bulatetskaya from Russia on classical accordion and Huixin Hu from China on violin, will perform a range of numbers, including classical pieces, folk songs, and Christmas favourites.And in the interval guests can enjoy a cup of coffee or tea with a choice of home-baked treats for free.A spokesperson said: ldquoThe Coffee Concerts series have been made possible courtesy of a grant awarded to the VC from the CAF Tourle Foundation and with the assistance of Live Music Now Scotland.Spaces for the Coffee Concert are limited, and tickets can be booked by emailing westlintonvillagecentre@gmail or by calling texting  . For those who are unable to attend in person, the performance will be streamed via Zoom. To register, click here.Twogether Duo will perform at West Linton Village Centre on Saturday, December  from -.pm.

title: winning-return-peebles-burgh-silver-band
story: PEEBLES Burgh Silver Band recently won the th Section of the Borders Entertainment Contest.On November  at The Buccleuch Centre in Langholm, Peebles Burgh Silver Ban joined a number of other Borders bands following the contestrsquos postponement last year due to the coronavirus pandemic.The bandrsquos musical director Peter Holmes prepared the programme which featured Philip Harperrsquos arrangement of Fat Bottom Girlsby Queen, The Road and the Miles to Dundeearranged by Alan Fernie, and I Will Follow Youfrom Sister Act.The band retained the trophy they won at the  competition.At the weekend the band performed at the annual Christmas lights switch-on in Peebles High Street.Peebles Burgh Silver Band now plans to perform on the High Street each Saturday morning throughout December from .am ndash weather permitting ndash and will host a Christmas Concert on Friday, December  in the Burgh Hall.Speaking about these upcoming events, a band spokesperson said: ldquoAll of these are much needed fundraising events for the Band following  months or so of no fundraising.ldquoWe are extremely grateful to sponsors and donors most recently The Provincial Grand Lodge of The Scottish Borders who provided a grant towards Youth Band tuition.ldquoWithout actions like this we would be unable to offer the free tuition and instruments to all.ldquoPBSB will be delighted to see you over the festive period and greatly appreciate all the local support it receives.Members of the Peebles Burgh Youth Band will also perform at the concert. Tickets for the concert can be purchased from band members or on the night.

title: christmas-arrives-peebles-switch-on-event
story: FESTIVE joy filled the streets in Peebles at the weekend as the townrsquos annual Christmas lights switch-on ed following the coronavirus pandemic.Visitors to the town and locals alike were treated to an afternoon filled with music and plenty of opportunities to find great gts.At .pm the lights were turned on by Paul Spence and Sophie Hamilton, the founders of the Peebles COVID- Mutual Support Group at the start of the pandemic.A spokesperson for Peebles Christmas Lights Association ndash which organised the event ndash shared on social media: ldquoThe people of Peebles and beyond you really are amazing, what an outstanding turnout this afternoon. We could not of wished for a better crowd of people.ldquoThe gamble well and truly paid off and our Association is very grateful.ldquoA huge thank you to all the stall holders and local businesses for their support today also, this would not of been possible without you all.ldquoThis is all put together and run by a small band of volunteers who have put hundreds of man hours into making this all possible, some of whom have been out since mid morning clearing cars from the street ready for the build up.ldquoThey all do this for the love of the town and what joy it brings to the town we try to keep everybody happy but sometimes this is just not possible.Musical performances on the day came courtesy of Peebles Burgh Silver Band, Peebles Ex-Servicemenrsquos Pipe Band, InChorus, and The Taylor Brothers. And stalls at the Christmas market along the High Street offered art, clothing, homewares and local produce.

title: weekend-rugby-round-up
story: The weather affected this weekendrsquos rugby card with a number of games postponed and one abandoned.In the Premiership, Hawick won the Borders derby beating Selkirk - at Philiphaugh. Kieran Clarkrsquos penalty gave the Souters the lead before Kirk Ford replied with a try which he converted to give the visitors a - half-time lead.Another Clark penalty reduced the deficit before referee Michael Todd awarded a penalty try to Hawick which Ford converted.A third Clark penalty finished the scoring.Jed-Forest travelled to Glasgow where they lost - to the Hawks. Captain Gregor Young suffered a rib injury forcing a change in formation then Paulo Ferreira saw yellow for a high tackle before Glasgow scored a converted try.Selkirk responded with a try from Lewis Young which Gary Munro converted then another penalty from Munro gave the Borderers a - lead.A converted try and a penalty from the Hawks secured the victory despite late pressure from Glasgow.In National League Division One Biggar beat Stirling Wolves - at Hartree Mill, Gala beat Ayr - at Netherdale, Kelso lost - to Highland in Inverness and the Melrose game against Boroughmuir was abandoned.In National League Division Two, Peebles game against Kirkcaldy was postponed.In National League Division Three Berwickrsquos game against Murrayfield Wanderers was abandoned.In National East League One Duns lost - to Broughton.In National East League Two Hawick Lindenrsquos game against Leith was postponed.In National East League Three Earlston lost - to Edinburgh Northern.In Reserve East League One Selkirk A lost - to Hawick Force at home and Jed-Forest A lost - away to Stewartrsquos Melville in the capital.In Reserve East League Two Kelso Sharks drew - with Gala A, Melrose Storm beat Preston Lodge - in Prestonpans and Peebles Reds game against Edinburgh Accies was postponed.In the Semi-Junior Borders League Kelso Harlequins beat Morpeth Colts - away from home.

title: covid-scotland-negative-lateral-flow-accepted-place-vaccine-passport-today
story: Negative lateral flow test resultswill be accepted in venues that require vaccine passports from today, after changes were made to the scheme by the Scottish government.Currently in Scotland you are required to show proof that you are fully vaccinatedfor entry intonightclubs, indoor live events with + people unseated, outdoor live events with + peopleunseated and any event with ,+ people.But from today a negative lateral flow test result at these venues will also be accepted.Heres everything you need to know...Can I use a lateral flow test to enter venues requiring a vaccine passport Yes, from Monday December , you can use proof of a negative lateral flow testto enter venues on the vaccine passport scheme in Scotland.Proof of vaccination will also still be accepted for these venues.If using a lateral flow test, it must have been taken within -hours prior to entry.You must report your lateral flow test result on the government website.How do I report my lateral flow test When you take your lateral flow test, you must report it on the Government website, which can be found here.You will then be sent a text or email confirming your result which can be used -negative - for entry to events requiring vaccine certication.Where can I get lateral flow tests Lateral flow tests are available for free from pharmacies and to order from the Scottish government website.Nicola Sturgeon also said that lateral flow tests would become available to collect in more venues in Scotland, including Christmas markets and sport centres.How can I download proof of vaccination You can download your vaccine passporton your smartphonevia theNHS Scotland Covid Status App.Alternatively, you can order a paper copyof your vaccine passport via yourvaccine portalor phoningthe specially designated Covid status helpline on  , open from am-pm every day..removeWill my booster jab show on my vaccine passport At the moment in Scotland, your booster vaccine will not show on your vaccine passport.However, the Scottish government has said it is working to change this as soon as possible to ensure the booster does appear on your vaccination certication.

title: social-lunches-fun-games-berwickshire-communities
story: BERWICKSHIRE Housing Associationrsquos BeFriend project is joining forces with Abundant Borders to take its Lunch Plus programme to towns and villages across the district.Abundant Borders first started Social Lunches in Coldstream in , with regular visits from BHA BeFriend ndash befrienders, befriendees and staff. Following the success of these weekly events it was decided to take these lunches to other communities across Berwickshire.With support from Berwickshire Alliance, and thanks to Scottish Government Covid Recovery Funding, this is now happening and each Thursday, Lunch Plus pops up in a dferent village! Abundant Borders staff and volunteers prepare homemade soup and sandwiches and BHA BeFriend arrange a iety of games and activities for everyone to enjoy.Karen Birch, Chief Officerat Abundant Borders, said: ldquoThe feedback has been incredible, and it is wonderful to be able to support even our most isolated villages and bring hearty food and good cheer to residents.ldquoItrsquos fantastic to be working so closely with the wonderful folk at BHA BeFriend and to be taking social lunches, fun and games to communities across Berwickshire. It is lovely to see people getting back out into their communities, meeting friends, chatting, enjoying freshly prepared food and having a bit of fun together after the couple of years that we have all had.Terri Bearhope, BeFriend Project Co-ordinator, said: ldquoItrsquos so good to be able to see people out and about again. Wersquove had fantastic feedback from people attending and we know that theyrsquore loving the chance to see old friends and meet new ones.ldquoAbundant Borders have been amazing, and their food is wonderful, second to none. The village halls have also been really supportive, not only do they let use their facilities, wersquove had committee members attending the lunches too.So far Lunch Plus events have been held in Grantshouse, Cockburnspath, Preston, Chirnside and Gordon and Foulden with others planned at Burnmouthand Greenlaw . They will also restart again in January.

title: borders-records-100-coronavirus-cases-weekend
story: THE Borders has seen a rise in cases of coronavirus over the weekend, new data shows.Updated figures were published by the Scottish Government at pm today .And the new data shows that the region saw  cases over the weekend, taking the total since the start of the pandemic to ,.:Storm Barra: Risk of more power cuts as Borders given yellow weather warningsOver the weekend Public Health Scotland were aware of a data reporting issue for results from the UK Government Pillar  lab tests. The issue was resolved, however, this could represent increased figures for today due to the backlog of cases being processed.There are currently  people in hospital in the Borders with recently confirmed cases of COVID-, according to the figures.On Friday, there were  people in hospital.Scotland has now recorded , cases since March last year.

title: new-travel-rules-scotland---changes-covid-travel-restrictions
story: More changes to the Covid travel rules in the UK have been introduced amid concerns surrounding the Omicron iant.Scientists are racing to understand more about the new iant originally identied in South Africa, with fears that it could be more transmissible than Delta.In order to try and curb the spread of Omicron, new travel rules have been imposed around the UK in a four nations approach.These rules apply to England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Irelanddue to the four nations approach to international travelthe governments have decided to take.Heres everything you need to know about travelling to the UK from abroad...Do I have to do a pre-departure test before flying to the UK From Tuesday December  at am, youwill be required to take a pre-departure test before flying to the UK.This applies to everyone over the age of , whether you are fully vaccinated or not.You must take this test within -hours before your flight to the UK departs.Do I have to do a PCR test when I arrive in the UK Yes,you are fully vaccinated you must take a PCR test within -hours of arriving in the UK.You must isolate until you receive the results of your test.If you are fully vaccinated andthe test is negative, you can leave isolation.What are the travel rules for red listed countries The following countries are currently on the red list:AngolaMalawiMozambiqueZambiaSouth AfricaBotswanaEswatiniLesothoNamibiaNigeriaZimbabwePeople travelling from red listed countries must take a PCR test prior to travel to the UK, isolate in a quarantine hotel when they arrive and take PCR tests on day  and day  of arrival.This applies to anyone travelling from red listed zones, whether vaccinated or not.What are the travel rules for people who are not fully vaccinated If you are not fully vaccinated and travelling to the UK from a non-red listed country, you must:.removetake a COVID- test ndash to be taken in the days before you travel to England book and pay for day  and day  COVID-PCRtestsndash to be taken after arrival in Englandquarantine at home or in the place you are staying for  full daystake your COVID-PCRtests ndash you mustbook these testsbefore you travel

title: nicola-sturgeon-covid-update-today-watch-live
story: Nicola Sturgeon will give her Covid update to Parliament this afternoon as Scotland continues to record cases of the Omicron iant.The iant, originally identied inSouth Africa, has caused concern around the world and prompted countries to introduce new measures to try and limit the spread.Scientists are racing to examine the potential impact of the Omicron iant which is feared to be more transmissible than Delta.In line with JCVI advice, the Scottish government confirmed last week it would offer all adults a booster jab to increase protection against the virus.Tighter restrictions on travel have also been introduced in the UK, with passengers travelling to England, Scotland, Wales or Northern Ireland from abroadrequired to take a pre-departure test from today, regardless of vaccine status.The first ministers statement comes the day after changes were made to the vaccine passport scheme in Scotland, which mean that people can now gain entry to events which require vaccine certication using a negative lateral flow result.As the country continues to grapple with the new Covid iant, heres everything you need to know about Nicola Sturgeons update today...What time is Nicola Sturgeon speaking today Nicola Sturgeon will give her update to Parliament on the Covid situation in Scotland around :pm this afternoon.It will depend on the topics before running to schedule, socould be just after :pm.Where can I watch Nicola Sturgeons Covid briefing You can watch the first ministersCovid update via the Scottish governments social media s.It will also be broadcast on BBC Scotland from :pm, and the statement is usually live tweeted from the SNP Twitter handle.What will Nicola Sturgeon say today As always, we will hear an update of the case rates in Scotland, with the figures published daily at pm.The first minister is also likely to give an overview of what the government knows about Omicron and its presence in Scotland..removeIf any further measures are to be introduced to curb the spread of the iant, we are likely to hear about them at the briefing this afternoon.

title: dominic-raab-defends-kabul-airlifts-whistleblowers-damning-claims
story: Dominic Raab has launched a defence of his handling of the evacuation of Afghanistan after a whistleblower alleged he led a ldquodysal and ldquochaotic operation while foreign secretary.Raphael Marshall, who worked for the Foreign Office during the effort, claimed that just % of Afghan nationals who applied to flee under one UK scheme received help.Some were murdered after being left behind in Kabul after the Taliban swept to power in August, he alleged in devastating written evidence to the Commons Foreign Affairs Committee.He alleged that Mr Raab ldquodid not fully understand the situation, was slow to rule on cases and requested they were reformatted ldquoin a well-presented table before making a decision.Mr Raab, who was moved to become Justice Secretary and Deputy Prime Minister after his handling of the crisis, sought to defend his record, having already been heavily criticised for holidaying in Crete as the Taliban were storming back to power in Afghanistan.ldquoItrsquos inaccurate in certain respects, the suggestion that junior desk officers were making decisions is just not correct, he told BBC Radio rsquos Today programme.ldquoTherersquos a dference between processing and deciding, so Irsquom afraid I donrsquot accept that characterisation.ldquoOn the charge it took several hours to make decisions, wersquore not talking about days, itrsquos not been suggested weeks, but several hours to make sure we had the facts, and that, as between myself, the Home Secretary and the Defence Secretary, decisions were made and actually I would suggest thatrsquos a reasonably swt turnaround.One of Mr Marshallrsquos allegations was that at one point the Cabinet minister ldquodeclined to make a decision on whether to admit a group of womenrsquos rights activists ldquowithout a properly formatted submission with a table setting out multiple cases.It would have been reasonable for Mr Raab to defer to the crisis centrersquos judgment but ldquoin the circumstances it is hard to explain why he reserved the decision for himself but failedto make it immediately, the former official said..removeYou can read the evidence given to the @CommonsForeignabout the @FCDOGovUKresponse to the Afghan crisis here: https:t.co lUtnIcnJZmdash Tom TugendhatDecember , Mr Raab responded: ldquoAnd in terms of presentation, of course with the volume of claims coming in I make no apology for saying I needed the clear facts that each case presented precisely so we can make swt decisions.ldquoSome of the criticism seems rather dislocated from the facts on the ground, the operational pressures that with the takeover of the Taliban, unexpected around the worldhellip I do think that not enough recognition has been given to quite how dficult it was.Among the flaws alleged by Mr Marshall was that the process of selecting who could be airlted out was ldquoarbitrary and dysal and that thousands of emails were going unread.He said that Foreign Office colleagues were ldquovisibly appalled by our chaotic system which was put in place as foreign forces withdrew after a -year occupation of Afghanistan.Tom Tugendhat, the senior Tory MP who chairs the Foreign Affairs Committee, said the ldquoserious allegations ldquogo to the heart of the failures of leadership around the Afghan disaster.vw,vw,px, px"Lt Cdr Alex Pelham Burns, a member of the UK Armed Forces during the evacuation of entitled personnel from Kabul airport He added that the ldquofailures betrayed our friends and allies and squandered decades of British and Nato effort while he described the evacuation effort as ldquoone of lack of interest, and bureaucracy over humanity.Shadow attorney general Emily Thornberry said Mr Raab should consider his position in the Cabinet in light of the testimony, which she said she was ldquodisgusted and ldquotruly shocked to hear.ldquoThere is plenty of evidence that Dominic Raab is not capable of making the sort of decisions that our country deserves in any way, the Labour MP told Sky News.Mr Marshall, who worked in the Afghan Special Cases team handling the cases of Afghans who were at risk because of their links with the UK, estimated ldquobetween , and , people including dependents applied for evacuation under the ldquoleave outside the rules category.But he calculated that ldquofewer than % of these people have received any assistance and stated that ldquoit is clear that some of those left behind have since been murdered by the Taliban.Askedhe recognised the whistleblowerrsquos figures, Mr Raab told Sky News: ldquoI donrsquot. But what is certainly true is that we had a lot of people rushing to get out of Afghanistan for all sorts of reasons.Mr Marshall also alleged that colleagues lacked knowledge of Afghanistan and that junior officials were ldquoscared by being asked to make hundreds of le-and-death decisions about which they knew nothing.ldquoDesperate and urgent emails, including those with titles such as ldquoPlease save my children, were also being opened but not actioned, he said.ldquoI believe the purpose of this system was to allow the Prime Minister and the then foreign secretary to inform MPs that there were no unread emails, Mr Marshall wrote.He also claimed that at one point he was the only person monitoring an inbox where pleas for help were directed.Foreign Office officials and Britainrsquos ambassador to Afghanistan, Sir Laurie Bristow, are due to give evidence to the select committee on Tuesday afternoon..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: Dominic Raab defends Kabul airlts after whistleblower us damning claims

title: covid-scotland-booster-jabs-appear-vaccine-passports-december-9
story: Scotlands deputy first minister confirmed this morning that the Covid booster jab will appear on Scottish vaccine passports for internationaltravel from December .Speaking on Good Morning Scotland, John Swinney said that proof of the booster jab would appear on vaccine passports for international travel from Thursday this week.He added that this would be extended to the domestic vaccine certicationscheme, however this would take slightly longer to implement.When asked whether booster jabs would be included in the vaccine passport scheme, the deputy first minister said: "For international travelit will from  December."And we will expand that for domestic certication but that will take us a little more time to do that. But the critical requirement is for international travel and those changes will be applied from  December."Why is it important that boosters show on vaccine passports To travel to some countries, you must have been fully vaccinated against Covidwithin a certain time limitprior to your visit, which ranges from -days to a year.With Covid jabs rolled out from late last year, it means that some people will already be barred from travelthey cannot provide proof of a booster jab.Proof of a booster jab will therefore help people to meet the vaccination requirements of certain countries.Who can get a booster jab in Scotland All adults in Scotland will be offered a booster vaccine as advised by the JCVI after results showed a third vaccine signicantly improved protection against serious infection.The booster jabs aim to curb a potentialwave of infections caused by the Omicron iant.So far, everyone aged  and over and people who are clinically vulnerable have been invited to book their booster jabs in Scotland.But soon, everyone over the age of  will beable to book a booster jab.These third doses will be offered no less than three months after the second dose of the vaccine was administered..removeThis time frame between second vaccine and booster jab has been cut from six months to three, as advised by the JCVI.
